Well, to a Christian that would make sense and the argument would be over. But what about those people who do not believe in the Bible? How can you prove to them that all religions are not one? A scripture does not prove anything to them.

Look at the faith structure of monotheistic religions versus polytheistic. How can they be one? Sure they share some of the same historical stories (eg., a great flood, a creation, etc, etc) but they are not one, and will definitely not agree on much.

I like Plato's belief on truth- as you know, he had levels of reality- shadows and effects of an object (television, for instance) were the lowest level of reality, sensual objects were the second lowest level of reality, then mathamatics and science were the second highest level of reality, and morality and truth were the highest level of reality. He believed there was only one truth- 1+1 is always 2, it's never 3 or four. There's no relativity. You're either right or you're wrong.

I'm not sure about that. True, religions typically have a higher place where a mighty god dwells, but that's about as far as you can take many of them. There is another big difference between Christianity and other religions that you seem to have confused. Christianity deals with the grace of God as the stairway for someone to get to Heaven. Good works are not required, they merely come out of faith. In other religions, especially Islam, one can only get to the higher place through performing good deeds or being a good person. 
 
 So maybe in one respect all religions are the same, but not as a whole.

I saw that one of the members on this site has a quote which states that "all religions are one". I have been researching this topic, and I am curious as to what your opinions are on this subject. What do you think? Are all religions "one"?

 
 All religions are certainly not one. Regardless of the higher plane theory, there are significantly different methods to getting there. The christian religion is the only one that claims you do not get there by anything you merit. You only get there by the mercy and grace of God through Identification with His Son. All other religions place the responsibility for the "higher plane" squarely on the individual who really has no capacity to do such a thing. It is like trying to lay a stone stairway one stone at a time to heaven. If it is infinitely far away (and it is according to all religions) then it is impossible for man to get there. Only the grace of God can bridge the gap. There is no other religion that claims the grace of God as unearned favor. All others consider it earned through their deeds.

if your trying to find a common factor of all religions, I think it is to give its members hope of a better state of being than they are in right now. it usually requires that the members collectively believe in some abstract concept, but through this belief the members feels better about themselves and have an optimistic outlook on life/afterlife

 oh, definitely all religions are not the same. in fact you might even say no 2 religions are the same. the details and nuances of religions are so extreme its sometimes mind-boggling and confusing. look at how many 'non-denominational christian' churches are out there. these actually say they believe in the same God and same Jesus of the same Bible, yet they are totally disunited on some minor interpretation of some part of the Bible, or even on an idea that the Bible doesnt even touch, and so they segregate from each other to the point of total disassociation, sometimes even slander! so while all religions have some fundamental commonality somewhere, they are not by any means all the same

 I would go so far as to agree that the christians, jews, and muslims, all believe in and worship the God of Abraham. However, they fundamentally disagree on what God is like. That would go for hinuism, buddism, zoroastrianism, new agism, crystals, L ron hubbard, etc.

 There is one difference between christians and the rest. Christians believe that their God, namely Yahweh, sent his son here to earth to live and die. Now, keep in mind, His son was 100% God and 100% man. This is the difference; that the Christian God showed himself to the world in flesh. We have proof and we put Christ as the mediator between us and heaven.

No, all religions are not the same religion.
 
 There are three primary western religions, and countless sects of each: Christianity, Judaism, and Islam. Much of the confusion is because these 3 follow the same 'family tree,' if you will. They do believe in one god, and they believe they all worship the same one (though many of them won't admit it or just don't know it). Where the differences come in is where they believe different historical figures (namely Jesus and Muhammad) fit into their religions. There are further two eastern religions which are absolutely and entirely different from both the western religions and each other: Hinduism and Buddhism.
 
 The comment that Buddhists just disagree on what God is like is ludicrous. Buddhism does not teach that there is a god. It is the only one of the 5 major religions which is not theistic; it is not about worship, or servitude to a deity, or anything like that. Before anyone comes along and says something like "but they think Buddha was a god!" let me just say that they don't. He is seen as a very wise man who became enlightened and tried to teach what he had realized. They don't think Buddha created the universe.
 
 The problem with this is that the prevalent Judaic-Christian powers in this country (and most of the western world) spend all of their time telling you 'the truth,' and nothing about other religions. I'd bet that if more people had any idea what Buddhism was like, alot of Christians, Jews, and Muslims would convert to it.
 
 Try this. Go to about.com. It's a great website. Go under the religion section, pull up in one window the page about Buddhism, and in one page pull up a more popular religion, I tried Mormonism. Compare the two. You'd be surprised, if you looked at it with an open mind (I don't follow any religion, so I kinda am open-minded in this regard), to find that the Mormon religion is far more superstitious, far more dangerous and scary, and it has a definate fantasy fell to it. In contrast, Buddhism really does seem like a very logical and reasonable religion.

There is one God who is the creator of all mankind. But there are many religions in the world: some come from the same origin: islam, christians and judaism.
 
 Islam believes that the word religion is a complete system of life. It [religion] teaches the individual his/her various roles/duties/responsibilities towards God, towards himself/herself, towards other human beings, animals and life...
 
 Man has duties as well as rights and he/she has the obligation to handle each with care unless he/she will have to pay the consequences of his/her actions.
 
 Many religions have common grounds but they differ in the way they worship God.

Many religions have nothing whatsoever to do with one another. You might lump all monotheism together, All polytheism and all Shamanism, and you're still left with Buddhism, Shinto and Confusionism.
 Even then we haven't considered Astrology, though that does bring up what exactly we define a religion as.
There is one mankind who is the creator of all God(s).

 And it's possible all are one. Nothings says God has to be consistent, logical or even sensical
All religions attempt to explain that which is unexplainable. While they do not all represent the same ideals, they all come from the same place...the minds of man. So the answer is yes, and no.
